Joint Source‚ÄìChannel Coding via Statistical Mechanics: Thermal Equilibrium Between the Source and the Channel ‚Ä†‚Ä†thanks: Part of this work was carried out during a visit in Hewlett‚ÄìPackard Laboratories, Palo Alto, CA, U.S.A., in the Summer of 2008.

Neri Merhav
Abstract

We examine the classical joint source‚Äìchannel coding problem from the viewpoint of statistical physics and demonstrate that in the random coding regime, the posterior probability distribution of the source given the channel output is dominated by source sequences, which exhibit a behavior that is highly parallel to that of thermal equilibrium between two systems of particles that exchange energy, where one system corresponds to the source and the other corresponds to the channel. The thermodynamical entopies of the dual physical problem are analogous to conditional and unconditional Shannon entropies of the source, and so, their balance in thermal equilibrium yields a simple formula for the mutual information between the source and the channel output, that is induced by the typical code in an ensemble of joint source‚Äìchannel codes under certain conditions. We also demonstrate how our results can be used in applications, like the wiretap channel, and how can it be extended to multiuser scenarios, like that of the multiple access channel.

Index Terms: joint source‚Äìchannel coding, statistical physics, thermal equilibrium, mutual information, entropy.

Department of Electrical Engineering

Technion - Israel Institute of Technology

Haifa 32000, ISRAEL

It turns out, as we shall see in Section 3 below, that the two problems have virtually identical answers (in a sense that will be made clear and precise therein), provided that the parameters TùëáTitalic_T and BùêµBitalic_B of the first problem are related to the parameters pùëùpitalic_p and qùëûqitalic_q of the second problem by

where kùëòkitalic_k is Boltzmann‚Äôs constant.

Thermal equilibrium between the two subsystems in the above described physical problem, dictates a certain balance between their thermodynamical entropies in order to arrive at the maximum total entropy (by the second law of thermodynamics) for the total energy possessed by the entire system at the given temperature TùëáTitalic_T. As the thermodynamical entropy, in its statistical‚Äìmechanical definition, is intimately related to the Shannon entropy, it turns out that this equilibrium relation between the thermodynamical entropies of the physical problem, gives rise to an analogous relation between Shannon entropies pertaining to the joint source‚Äìchannel coding problem in the random coding regime. In particular, it relates the entropy of the source to its conditional entropy given the channel output, whose difference is exactly the mutual information between the source and the channel output. The final outcome of this is a simple formula for calculating the mutual information rate between the input and the output of a coded system for the typical code in a given ensemble under certain conditions. This calculation builds strongly on the random energy model (REM) of spin glasses due to Derrida [3, 4, 5] and its relation to the random code ensemble (RCE) as described in [12].

Clearly, under the regime of reliable communication, the mutual information rate between the source and the channel output coincides with the entropy rate of the source, as the conditional entropy rate of the source given the channel output vanishes. Thus, the problem of calculating the mutual information under reliable communication conditions is easy and in fact, not quite interesting. The same calculation, however, when the conditions of reliable communication are not met, appears less trivial. But what would be the motivation for such a calculation?

Here are just a few examples that motivate this: Consider a user that, in addition to its desired signal, receives also a relatively strong interfering signal (codeword), which is intended to other users, and which comes from a codebook whose rate exceeds the capacity of this crosstalk channel between the interferer and our user, so that the user cannot fully decode this interference. Nonetheless, our user would like to learn as much as possible on the interfering signal for many possible reasons: For example, the user would like to learn the interference signal in order to identify where it originates from, or in order to estimate it and subtract it (intereference cancellation). The mutual information rate, call it IùêºIitalic_I, between the interference signal and the channel output then gives some assessment concerning the quality of this estimation. For one thing, D‚Å¢(I)ùê∑ùêºD(I)italic_D ( italic_I ), where D‚Å¢(‚ãÖ)ùê∑‚ãÖD(\cdot)italic_D ( ‚ãÖ ) is the distortion‚Äìrate function of the source, is a lower bound to the distortion in estimating this signal. Moreover, if the channel is Gaussian, one can calculate the exact minimum mean square error (MMSE) from the mutual information rate IùêºIitalic_I by taking its derivative w.r.t.¬†the signal‚Äìto‚Äìnoise ratio (SNR) [9]. Another application comes from scenarios where the above described receiver is a hositle party (an eavesdropper), from which one would like to conceal information as much as possible. The natural setup, in this context, is that of the wiretap channel (cf.¬†[14] as well as many follow‚Äìup papers), where excess channel noise beyond capacity is harnessed as an effective key that secures data communication. As we show in the sequel, the mutual information rate between the transmitted message and the eavesdropper, which suffers from this excess noise, is strongly related to the equivocation, which is a customary measure of security in Shannon‚Äìtheoretic secrecy systems.

The outline of this paper is as follows. In Section 2, we establish notation conventions. In Section 3, we provide some basic background of elementary statistical physics, which will be needed in the sequel. In Section 4, we derive our main result, which is a formula for the mutual information rate. In Section 5, we demonstrate how it is applied for the wiretap channel, and finally, in Section 6, we demonstrate how our results can be extended to multiuser scenarios, like that of the multiple access channel.

2 Notation Conventions

Throughout this paper, scalar random variables (RV‚Äôs) will be denoted by the capital letters, like SùëÜSitalic_S, XùëãXitalic_X, and YùëåYitalic_Y, their sample values will be denoted by the respective lower case letters, and their alphabets will be denoted by the respective calligraphic letters. A similar convention will apply to random vectors and their sample values, which will be denoted with same symbols with the bold face font. Thus, for example, ùëøùëøXbold_italic_X will denote a random nùëõnitalic_n-vector (X1,‚Ä¶,Xn)subscriptùëã1‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëõ(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and ùíô=(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)ùíôsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõ\mbox{\boldmath$x$}=(x_{1},...,x_{n})bold_italic_x = ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a specific vector value in ùí≥nsuperscriptùí≥ùëõ{\cal X}^{n}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the nùëõnitalic_n-th Cartesian power of ùí≥ùí≥{\cal X}caligraphic_X. Whenever clarity and unambiguity will require it, these letters will be subscripted by the names of the relevant RV‚Äôs, following the standard notation conventions in the literaure, for example, PSsubscriptùëÉùëÜP_{S}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will denote the probability distribution of a random variable SùëÜSitalic_S, PX|YsubscriptùëÉconditionalùëãùëåP_{X|Y}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X | italic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will denote the conditional probability distribution of XùëãXitalic_X given YùëåYitalic_Y, and so on. 3 Background

In this section, we provide a brief account of the very basic background in statistical physics, which is needed for this paper.

Consider a physical system with NùëÅNitalic_N of particles, which can be in a variety of microscopic states (‚Äòmicrostates‚Äô), defined by combinations of of physical quantities associated with these particles, e.g., positions, momenta, angular momenta, spins, etc., of all NùëÅNitalic_N particles. For each such microstate of the system, which we shall designate by a vector ùíî=(s1,‚Ä¶,sN)ùíîsubscriptùë†1‚Ä¶subscriptùë†ùëÅ\mbox{\boldmath$s$}=(s_{1},\ldots,s_{N})bold_italic_s = ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), there is an associated energy, given by an Hamiltonian (energy function), ‚Ñ∞‚Å¢(ùíî)‚Ñ∞ùíî{\cal E}(\mbox{\boldmath$s$})caligraphic_E ( bold_italic_s ). For example, if si=(ùíëi,ùíìi)subscriptùë†ùëñsubscriptùíëùëñsubscriptùíìùëñs_{i}=(\mbox{\boldmath$p$}_{i},\mbox{\boldmath$r$}_{i})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where ùíëisubscriptùíëùëñ\mbox{\boldmath$p$}_{i}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the momentum vector of particle number iùëñiitalic_i and ùíìisubscriptùíìùëñ\mbox{\boldmath$r$}_{i}bold_italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is its position vector, then classically, ‚Ñ∞‚Å¢(ùíî)=‚àëi=1N[‚Äñùíëi‚Äñ22‚Å¢m+m‚Å¢g‚Å¢zi]‚Ñ∞ùíîsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅdelimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptùíëùëñ22ùëöùëöùëîsubscriptùëßùëñ{\cal E}(\mbox{\boldmath$s$})=\sum_{i=1}^{N}[\frac{\|\mbox{\boldmath$p$}_{i}\|^{2}}{2m}+mgz_{i}]caligraphic_E ( bold_italic_s ) = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG + italic_m italic_g italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], where mùëömitalic_m is the mass of each particle, zisubscriptùëßùëñz_{i}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is its height ‚Äì one of the coordinates of ùíìisubscriptùíìùëñ\mbox{\boldmath$r$}_{i}bold_italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and gùëîgitalic_g is the gravitation constant.

One of the most fundamental results in statistical physics (based on the law of energy conservation and the basic postulate that all microstates of the same energy level are equiprobable) is that when the system is in thermal equilibrium with its environment, the probability of a microstate ùíîùíîsbold_italic_s is given by the Boltzmann‚ÄìGibbs distribution

The role of the partition function is by far deeper than just being a normalization factor, as it is actually the key quantity from which many macroscopic physical quantities can be derived, for example, the free energy111The free energy means the maximum work that the system can carry out in any process of fixed temperature. The second law of thermodynamics asserts that in an isolated system (which does not exchange energy with its environment), the total entropy cannot decrease, and hence in equilibrium, it reaches its maximum.

This is true regardless of whether the communication is reliable or not, i.e., it continues to hold no matter whether the entropy rate of the source is smaller or larger than ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª times the mutual information between the input and the output of the channel.

Returning to the general discussion above, note that the same considerations continue to hold even if one of the systems, say, the second one, has an effective negative entropy, that is, Œ©n,Œ¥(2)‚Å¢([(1+Œª)‚Å¢œµ0‚àíœµ*]/Œª)<1superscriptsubscriptŒ©ùëõùõø2delimited-[]1ùúÜsubscriptitalic-œµ0superscriptitalic-œµùúÜ1\Omega_{n,\delta}^{(2)}([(1+\lambda)\epsilon_{0}-\epsilon^{*}]/\lambda)<1roman_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_Œ¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ ( 1 + italic_Œª ) italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] / italic_Œª ) < 1, which means that for each microstate ùíîùíîsbold_italic_s of the first subsystem with per‚Äìparticle energy œµ*superscriptitalic-œµ\epsilon^{*}italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, only a fraction of the compatible combined microstates {(ùíî,ùíî‚Ä≤)}ùíîsuperscriptùíî‚Ä≤\{(\mbox{\boldmath$s$},\mbox{\boldmath$s$}^{\prime})\}{ ( bold_italic_s , bold_italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } have noramilzed energy œµ0subscriptitalic-œµ0\epsilon_{0}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Of course, Œ©N,n,Œ¥^‚Å¢(œµ*)subscriptŒ©ùëÅùëõ^ùõøsuperscriptitalic-œµ\Omega_{N,n,\hat{\delta}}(\epsilon^{*})roman_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N , italic_n , over^ start_ARG italic_Œ¥ end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) must be larger than 1. In the sequel, we shall see that in the joint source‚Äìchannel coding problem, the source and the channel constitute a mechanism which is highly parallel to that of equilibrium energy‚Äìsharing between two subsystems in a heat bath, where the subsystem corresponding to the channel has a negative effective thermodynamic entropy in this sense.

We should comment that in order to determine the energy sharing between the two subsystems in the above discussion, it was not necessary to consider how they thermally interact with each other and to go through the weighted supremal convolution between their entropies, as we did. We could have determined these energies simply by considering the equilibrium of each one of the subsystems individually with the heat bath,333When doing so, the other system then becomes part of the heat bath anyway. thus equating the derivative of each one of the entropy functions to Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤. Nonetheless, we have deliberately chosen to present the supremal convolution because in the sequel, it is this relation that will lead to the derivation of the mutual information in the joint source‚Äìchannel coding problem.

Z‚Å¢(Œ≤|ùíö)=Œî‚àëùíî‚ààùíÆNexp‚Å°{‚àíŒ≤‚Å¢[‚Ñ∞S‚Å¢(ùíî)+‚Ñ∞C‚Å¢(ùíô‚Å¢(ùíî),ùíö)]}.superscriptŒîùëçconditionalùõΩùíösubscriptùíîsuperscriptùíÆùëÅùõΩdelimited-[]subscript‚Ñ∞ùëÜùíîsubscript‚Ñ∞ùê∂ùíôùíîùíöZ(\beta|\mbox{\boldmath$y$})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{\mbox{\boldmath$s$}\in{\cal S}^{N}}\exp\{-\beta[{\cal E}_{S}(\mbox{\boldmath$s$})+{\cal E}_{C}(\mbox{\boldmath$x$}(\mbox{\boldmath$s$}),\mbox{\boldmath$y$})]\}.italic_Z ( italic_Œ≤ | bold_italic_y ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Œî end_ARG end_RELOP ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s ‚àà caligraphic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp { - italic_Œ≤ [ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) + caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ( bold_italic_s ) , bold_italic_y ) ] } .

In the course of studying the properties of a typical realization of the joint source‚Äìchannel partition function, pertaining to a given code ensemble, we will make a few observations, which were already mentioned briefly in the Introduction:

  1. 1.

    Similarly as results that have already been observed in the context of the pure channel coding problem [12], the statistical‚Äìmechanical system pertaining to Z‚Å¢(Œ≤|ùíö)ùëçconditionalùõΩùíöZ(\beta|\mbox{\boldmath$y$})italic_Z ( italic_Œ≤ | bold_italic_y ) undergoes a phase transition, which corresponds, in the realm of coded systems, to the transition between reliable and unreliable communication, namely, the point at which the entropy rate of the source exceeds the mutual information between the input and the output of the channel.

  2. 2.

    When identifying the set of source vectors {ùíî}ùíî\{\mbox{\boldmath$s$}\}{ bold_italic_s } that dominates Z‚Å¢(Œ≤|ùíö)ùëçconditionalùõΩùíöZ(\beta|\mbox{\boldmath$y$})italic_Z ( italic_Œ≤ | bold_italic_y ) (i.e., those that contribute most to Z‚Å¢(Œ≤|ùíö)ùëçconditionalùõΩùíöZ(\beta|\mbox{\boldmath$y$})italic_Z ( italic_Œ≤ | bold_italic_y )) above the phase transition temperature, one observes a situation that parallels that of thermal equilibrium between two physical subsystems, one corresponding to the source and the other corresponds to the channel. To be more specific, if ‚Ñ∞‚Å¢(ùíî,ùíö)=‚Ñ∞S‚Å¢(ùíî)+‚Ñ∞C‚Å¢(ùíô‚Å¢(ùíî),ùíö)‚Ñ∞ùíîùíösubscript‚Ñ∞ùëÜùíîsubscript‚Ñ∞ùê∂ùíôùíîùíö{\cal E}(\mbox{\boldmath$s$},\mbox{\boldmath$y$})={\cal E}_{S}(\mbox{\boldmath$s$})+{\cal E}_{C}(\mbox{\boldmath$x$}(\mbox{\boldmath$s$}),\mbox{\boldmath$y$})caligraphic_E ( bold_italic_s , bold_italic_y ) = caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) + caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ( bold_italic_s ) , bold_italic_y ) is thought of as the total ‚Äòenergy‚Äô shared by the source and the code/channel, then the dominant messages {ùíî}ùíî\{\mbox{\boldmath$s$}\}{ bold_italic_s } split this total average energy between the source and the channel components in a way that corresponds to thermal equilibrium between the two parallel physical subsystems.

  3. 3.

    The balance between the thermodynamical entropies of the two physical subsystems that lie in equilibrium, as described in item no.¬†2, is identified with the simple relation between the corresponding Shannon entropies of the source, namely, the unconditional source entropy and the conditional entropy given the channel output, whose difference is the mutual information between the source and the channel output. This gives rise to a simple formula of the mutual information rate induced by a typical code in the ensemble.

In analogy to the definitions and the assumptions outlined in Section 3, we now make a few definitions and assumptions concerning the joint source‚Äìchannel coding model.

5 Application to the Wiretap Channel

In this section, we demonstrate how our results apply to the wiretap channel. Wyner, in his well‚Äìknown paper on the wiretap channel [14], studied the problem of secure communication across a degraded broadcast channel, without using a secret key, where the legitimate receiver has access to the output of the good channel and the wiretapper receives the output of the bad channel. In that paper, Wyner characterized the optimum trade‚Äìoff between reliable coding rates and the equivocation at the wiretapper, which was defined in terms of the conditional entropy of the source given the output of the bad channel, observed by the wire‚Äìtapper.

Consider a DMS PùëÉPitalic_P as before, and a cascade of two finite alphabet DMC‚Äôs: WY|XsubscriptùëäconditionalùëåùëãW_{Y|X}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y | italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT followed immediately by WZ|YsubscriptùëäconditionalùëçùëåW_{Z|Y}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z | italic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, both777The notation of the output of the second channel, ZùëçZitalic_Z, should not be confused with the notation of the partition function since we do not refer the partition function in this section. operating at a relative rate of ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª channel symbols per source symbol. The source ùíî‚ààùíÆNùíîsuperscriptùíÆùëÅ\mbox{\boldmath$s$}\in{\cal S}^{N}bold_italic_s ‚àà caligraphic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is encoded to a channel input vector ùíô‚Å¢(ùíî)‚ààùí≥nùíôùíîsuperscriptùí≥ùëõ\mbox{\boldmath$x$}(\mbox{\boldmath$s$})\in{\cal X}^{n}bold_italic_x ( bold_italic_s ) ‚àà caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, n=Œª‚Å¢NùëõùúÜùëÅn=\lambda Nitalic_n = italic_Œª italic_N, and then transmitted. Indeed, if we represent the transmitted codeword ùíôùíôxbold_italic_x as f‚Å¢(c‚Å¢(ùíî),ùíñ)ùëìùëêùíîùíñf(c(\mbox{\boldmath$s$}),\mbox{\boldmath$u$})italic_f ( italic_c ( bold_italic_s ) , bold_italic_u ), where c‚Å¢(ùíî)ùëêùíîc(\mbox{\boldmath$s$})italic_c ( bold_italic_s ) stands for the bit string of the lossless compression of ùíîùíîsbold_italic_s, indicating the bin index using n‚Å¢H‚Å¢(S)/ŒªùëõùêªùëÜùúÜnH(S)/\lambdaitalic_n italic_H ( italic_S ) / italic_Œª nats, and ùíñùíñubold_italic_u as an independent random bit string of length n‚Å¢I‚Å¢(X*;Z*)ùëõùêºsuperscriptùëãsuperscriptùëçnI(X^{*};Z^{*})italic_n italic_I ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) nats, then we have the following: One the one hand,

H‚Å¢(ùëø|ùíÅ)‚â§H‚Å¢(c‚Å¢(ùë∫),ùëº|ùíÅ)=H‚Å¢(c‚Å¢(ùë∫)|ùíÅ)+H‚Å¢(ùëº|ùíÅ,c‚Å¢(ùë∫))ùêªconditionalùëøùíÅùêªùëêùë∫conditionalùëºùíÅùêªconditionalùëêùë∫ùíÅùêªconditionalùëºùíÅùëêùë∫H(\mbox{\boldmath$X$}|\mbox{\boldmath$Z$})\leq H(c(\mbox{\boldmath$S$}),\mbox{\boldmath$U$}|\mbox{\boldmath$Z$})=H(c(\mbox{\boldmath$S$})|\mbox{\boldmath$Z$})+H(\mbox{\boldmath$U$}|\mbox{\boldmath$Z$},c(\mbox{\boldmath$S$}))italic_H ( bold_italic_X | bold_italic_Z ) ‚â§ italic_H ( italic_c ( bold_italic_S ) , bold_italic_U | bold_italic_Z ) = italic_H ( italic_c ( bold_italic_S ) | bold_italic_Z ) + italic_H ( bold_italic_U | bold_italic_Z , italic_c ( bold_italic_S ) )

where the term H‚Å¢(ùëº|ùíÅ,c‚Å¢(ùë∫))ùêªconditionalùëºùíÅùëêùë∫H(\mbox{\boldmath$U$}|\mbox{\boldmath$Z$},c(\mbox{\boldmath$S$}))italic_H ( bold_italic_U | bold_italic_Z , italic_c ( bold_italic_S ) ) essentially vanishes since, as mentioned above, every bin forms a channel sub‚Äìcode that is reliably decodable by the eavesdropper. On the other hand,

H‚Å¢(ùëø|ùíÅ)=H‚Å¢(ùëø)‚àíI‚Å¢(ùëø;ùíÅ),ùêªconditionalùëøùíÅùêªùëøùêºùëøùíÅH(\mbox{\boldmath$X$}|\mbox{\boldmath$Z$})=H(\mbox{\boldmath$X$})-I(\mbox{\boldmath$X$};\mbox{\boldmath$Z$}),italic_H ( bold_italic_X | bold_italic_Z ) = italic_H ( bold_italic_X ) - italic_I ( bold_italic_X ; bold_italic_Z ) ,

thus the equivocation achieved is:

H‚Å¢(ùë∫|ùíÅ)‚â•H‚Å¢(c‚Å¢(ùë∫)|ùíÅ)‚àºH‚Å¢(ùëø)‚àíI‚Å¢(ùëø;ùíÅ)ùêªconditionalùë∫ùíÅùêªconditionalùëêùë∫ùíÅsimilar-toùêªùëøùêºùëøùíÅH(\mbox{\boldmath$S$}|\mbox{\boldmath$Z$})\geq H(c(\mbox{\boldmath$S$})|\mbox{\boldmath$Z$})\sim H(\mbox{\boldmath$X$})-I(\mbox{\boldmath$X$};\mbox{\boldmath$Z$})italic_H ( bold_italic_S | bold_italic_Z ) ‚â• italic_H ( italic_c ( bold_italic_S ) | bold_italic_Z ) ‚àº italic_H ( bold_italic_X ) - italic_I ( bold_italic_X ; bold_italic_Z )

where the first term in the r.h.s.¬†is essentially n‚Å¢[H‚Å¢(S)/Œª+I‚Å¢(X*;Z*)]ùëõdelimited-[]ùêªùëÜùúÜùêºsuperscriptùëãsuperscriptùëçn[H(S)/\lambda+I(X^{*};Z^{*})]italic_n [ italic_H ( italic_S ) / italic_Œª + italic_I ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] and the second term, which is a mutual information induced by a code above capacity, can be evaluated using our above results, provided that the channel code is randomly selected from an ensemble that satisfies our assumptions. For example, if the codewords are chosen i.i.d.¬†according to the distribution of X*superscriptùëãX^{*}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then I‚Å¢(ùëø;ùíÅ)ùêºùëøùíÅI(\mbox{\boldmath$X$};\mbox{\boldmath$Z$})italic_I ( bold_italic_X ; bold_italic_Z ) is approximately n‚Å¢I‚Å¢(X*;Z*)ùëõùêºsuperscriptùëãsuperscriptùëçnI(X^{*};Z^{*})italic_n italic_I ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and then full secrecy is achieved as H‚Å¢(ùë∫|ùíÅ)/Nùêªconditionalùë∫ùíÅùëÅH(\mbox{\boldmath$S$}|\mbox{\boldmath$Z$})/Nitalic_H ( bold_italic_S | bold_italic_Z ) / italic_N is essentially equal to H‚Å¢(S)ùêªùëÜH(S)italic_H ( italic_S ). Nonetheless, since the rate of the code [H(S)/Œª+I(X*;Z*)[H(S)/\lambda+I(X^{*};Z^{*})[ italic_H ( italic_S ) / italic_Œª + italic_I ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is less than I‚Å¢(X*;Y*)ùêºsuperscriptùëãsuperscriptùëåI(X^{*};Y^{*})italic_I ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), the legtimate decoder can still decode reliably. Out results can be used also to assess the secrecy achieved by random varlaibles other than i.i.d.¬†according to X*superscriptùëãX^{*}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, while ensuring that the good decode can still decode reliably.

6 Extension to Multiuser Settings

The above ideas can be extended in a natural manner to multiuser communication situations, and in this section, we demonstrate this for the multiple access channel (MAC), where the underlying principle is again thermal equilibrium between the subsystems pertaining to the different users and that of the channel. As before, our focus is on the regime where reliable communication cannot hold (the paramegnetic phase).

As an example, consider a randomly selected joint source‚Äìchannel code for a MAC with two users, in the following setting.
